title: 9/11 Memorial Is a Beacon for Communities Facing Tragedies
text:
On any given day, the National September 11 Memorial & Museum welcomes thousands of visitors to its site at the location of the former World Trade Center. But as the institution prepares to mark the 18th anniversary on Wednesday of the event that claimed nearly 3,000 lives, it is finding a role for itself far beyond its lower Manhattan home.

Increasingly, it is being tapped to advise communities that have faced tragedies of their own.

The locales are almost too numerous to mention, September 11 Memorial & Museum officials said, but they include such places as Boston (scene of the 2013 Boston Marathon bombing), Orlando, Fla., (the 2016 Pulse nightclub shooting) and most recently, El Paso, Texas, (the Aug. 3 Walmart shooting).

Museum officials said it wasn’t their initial intention to take on this consulting role, but it has evolved that way.

“We’re as surprised by it as anyone else,” said Alice M. Greenwald, president and chief executive of the institution.

Lines form at the entrance of the museum in New York City. Photo: Oscar Durand for The Wall Street Journal

The memorial opened in 2011, and the museum followed three years later. Both have become among New York City’s most significant tourist attractions, with the memorial alone having drawn 48 million visitors in the past eight years.

In many ways, the September 11 Memorial & Museum has been pressed into the advisory role because there are few institutions in the country charged with its mission: to chronicle an event in recent history and to place that event in a larger, ever-evolving context.

Wedded to that is a level of empathy the September 11 Memorial & Museum brings to the job, said Barbara Poma, owner of Orlando’s Pulse nightclub. As she began considering a memorial at her site, Ms. Poma reached out to the institution’s team.

“When they received my call, it was with open arms,” she said.

The assistance offered by the September 11 Memorial & Museum takes different forms, officials with the institution said. In many instances, they advise communities about the kind of material to gather and archive following a tragedy, from the oral testimonies of those connected to the event to the notes and trinkets left at makeshift memorials.

George Mironis, a volunteer at the museum, is a 9/11 survivor and decorated his vest with pins he received as gifts. Photo: Oscar Durand for The Wall Street Journal

Archiving these modern-day tragedies is challenging because there are few established protocols for what to do, said Erica Marin, registrar of the El Paso Museum of History. The museum reached out to the September 11 team following the Walmart shooting.

But the advice provided by the September 11 team comes in other forms. For example, Ms. Poma said she sought counsel about board development for the Pulse memorial foundation she has created.

At times, the support the September 11 team offers has little to do with creating memorials, however. In the case of the 2018 shooting at the Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla., the September 11 Memorial & Museum simply made itself available to students from the school when they visited New York and connected them with family members of 9/11 victims.

“We wanted to give them a human touch,” said Ms. Greenwald.

Stan Kopman, left, a docent at the museum, explains the meaning of the Memorial Glade. Photo: Oscar Durand for The Wall Street Journal

For the September 11 Memorial & Museum, the support offered to communities fits into its broader outreach efforts.

The institution has worked with law-enforcement agencies, such as the New York Police Department, to provide tours to recruits. It also hosts a variety of events, including a field hearing this past Monday of the U.S. Senate Committee on Homeland Security & Governmental Affairs.

The idea, said Ms. Greenwald, is to make the September 11 Memorial & Museum more than a place to pay one’s respects. She sees it as an institution that can serve as a gathering place and a source for information and ideas on a range of subjects.

“We can provide perspective,” Ms. Greenwald said.

Write to Charles Passy at cpassy@wsj.com
description: The National September 11 Memorial & Museum increasingly is being tapped to advise communities that have faced tragedies of their own.
